item.title: How much has biotechnology evolved since the 1980s?
item.description: The difficulty with extraction and purification of secondary metabolites is that it is 1) difficult 2) costly and 3) time consuming. MacQueen (1988) highlighted some problems with the extraction of secondary metabolites and many of those difficulties are still problematic today. Current technologies include: Biopharming or plant molecular farming is to genetically modify plants for the manufacturing of various pharmaceuticals and industrial products. For example, genetically modifying tobacco with desired therapeutic proteins could lead to the manufacturing of vaccines and antibodies to treat life-long diseases such as cancer.

item.title: Examples of the uses of secondary metabolites
item.description: Although plants may survive without the use of secondary metabolites. The extracts of these compounds have great advantages: For example Shikonine is a green pigment that is manufactured by Lithospermum eryrorhizon cells which has been used for cosmetics such as lipsticks. Vincristine is manufactured by Vinca rosea and is helpful for treating cancer. Other compounds which used to treat cardiovascular disorders include Digoxin compounds. And Pyrithrin is a compound used as an insecticide.

item.title: Are secondary metabolites less important?
item.description: Secondary metabolites were first distinguished from primary metabolites by Kossel (Bourgaud et al., 2001). However, although the traditional name “secondary metabolites” has existed for decades name, this name may give the impression that these chemicals are of less importance than primary metabolites. This is not always the case, for example, if a secondary metabolite is used for pollination purposes, the plant may only need the chemical as a mature plant but if the plant cannot produce by asexual means, it would need such chemicals to further its population.

item.title: A closer look at secondary metabolites
item.description: Whilst primary metabolites include only a small range of compounds (proteins, carbohydrates, and lipids), secondary metabolites entail a wide range of compounds (alkaloids, steroids, flavonoids, tannins, phenolics etcetera) (Class notes, Prof Finnie, 2019). Most secondary metabolite compounds are produced by plants as a defence mechanism, protecting themselves against toxins and pathogens in their surroundings (Bourgaud et al., 2001). item.title: An overview - Plants, biotechnology and metabolites
item.description: Plants have been used as a source of traditional medicine for decades (Fennell et al., 2004). The authors (Fennell et al., 2004) mention the important uses of plant compounds, they include antibacterial, anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, antifungal, antischistosomal, anthelminthic, antimalarial and anti-amoebic (Fennell et al., 2004).
